meanings.definition: Immerge: to plunge into or immerse oneself in something
meanings.sent1: She decided to immerge herself in the world of painting and spent hours creating beautiful artwork.
meanings.sent2: The children love to immerge themselves in the cool water of the swimming pool on hot summer days.
meanings.sent3: After a long day at work, he would immerge himself in his favorite book to relax and unwind.
meanings.sent4: The music was so captivating that it seemed to immerge the audience into a different realm of emotions.
meanings.sent5: As the sun set, the colors of the sky seemed to immerge with the horizon in a breathtaking display.

meanings.definition: Immerge: to disappear or submerge completely
meanings.sent1: The magician made the coin immerge into thin air, leaving the audience in awe.
meanings.sent2: The submarine started to immerge into the depths of the ocean, exploring the unknown underwater world.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to immerge itself under the blankets, thinking it could hide from the vet.
meanings.sent4: As the storm approached, the city began to immerge into darkness, with only distant lightning illuminating the sky.
meanings.sent5: The shadows seemed to immerge from the corners of the room, creating an eerie atmosphere.

meanings.definition: Immerge: to involve deeply or absorb completely
meanings.sent1: The new project at work required her to immerge herself in research to understand all the details.
meanings.sent2: The captivating movie made the audience immerge themselves in the storyline, feeling every emotion of the characters.
meanings.sent3: The delicious aroma of the freshly baked cookies seemed to immerge everyone in the kitchen, drawing them closer.
meanings.sent4: The forest's tranquility seemed to immerge him in a sense of peace and calmness, away from the chaos of the city.
meanings.sent5: The scent of the flowers seemed to immerge the entire garden in a sweet fragrance, attracting bees and butterflies.
